text: Thank you so much for joining me today.
Of course. Thank you. It's a great day.
If you'd be so kind, please tell me a little bit
about your background and what you do at People.ai.
Sure.
We're a revenue intelligence company,
so what we do is we help sales leaders
actually make decisions faster using data.
So hence security is top of mind for all of us
because we ingest our data and give you data
to make those analytical decisions.
So when I talk to a lot of CISOs,
we talk about the sort of evolution of the CISO role
over time, right?
And for a long time the CISO role was looked as a, you know,
I'm a technical security expert
and really only brought in to sort of fight fires
if something bad were to happen within an organization.
But today, the majority of the successful CISOs
that we see out there are really business leaders first
and maybe security practitioners second.
Can you talk a little bit about how you've seen
the role evolve and perhaps with your experiences?
Yeah, absolutely.
I think if you take it back five years, 10 years,
CISOs were actually spot on.
Our job was to protect the company.
We're security experts.
We're in the background, behind the scenes.
And if you look at it today and going forward,
security is so paramount in everyone's mind.
In every industry.
Security actually needs to be up front, right?
So I always use the phrase in the company,
"Bring security to the forefront.
Don't play defense."
Tell the customer about your security.
Tell the customer how important security is to the company
because then the customer looking at you is like,
"Oh, you know what you're talking about."
They feel more secure just talking to you
because you're being proactive, right?
Earning that trust.
Yeah. So you're building that trust.
And I would say trust is built in layers.
When you go to the executive committee
it's always about what they've heard.
You always remember these board members, E-staff,
they're friends, and they're like,
"Did you hear about that hack?"
and "Did you hear about this?"
So what I do is actually talk about security at large.
What's happening in our space?
Whether we're impacted or not impacted,
it's always great to kind of bring that
to the forefront in those meetings
because in the back of their mind it's like,
"Oh, my friend was telling me about this hack
and this is what happened in our environment
but this is why we weren't impacted."
It's taken more about telling a story,
educating, being more relative and connecting
to each other's thoughts and ideas.
And I think that's where security becomes more powerful.
Interesting.
So when you're having those board level conversations
and you're telling these stories,
are you talking about, you know,
we had X amount of vulnerabilities
and we were able to patch them in this amount of time?
Or are you talking in terms of risk
around like the P&L to the business?
If you look at different boards,
and I've been fortunate to be
in a couple of different companies,
every board is a little different.
Some boards are more about, "Hey, educate us."
And then there are boards who are basically smart enough
and savvy enough, who may not be security practitioners
but are very well informed about the space.
So the way I do it is I do start out,
what are we doing in the industry?
What is our industry doing?
What is security meaning to them?
Then I actually get into business values or capabilities
that tie back to our bottom line.
I will tell you that you always need to have the data
to back your own security posture.
There could be a spike in, say,
the phishing attempts have been 10x last month.
You can't go into a board meeting and say,
"So how is our phishing campaign?"
You know, "Let me get back to you."

Bad answer.
Right.
You have to be prepared, you have to have the data.
You can say, you know,
"Slide 54 actually has our current versus last..."
End of the day I always think of board members as
make it easy for them.
Sure.
Make it easy. Make it easy to digest the information.
Then, you know, your job is easier
and then everyone comes out on the same path.
So making it easy for the board is one thing,
but then if we switch to inside the company,
you also want to make it easy for product
and development teams to do things the right way.
Yes.
The secure way.
Can you talk a little bit about
maybe some of the mechanisms you've set up to enable that?
And you know, I'll say something.
Maybe it's too simple.
It's having a conversation.
If you actually have a conversation,
you communicate and you sit down with the CTO,
the chief engineer, chief architect, and you talk about...
A lot of people talk about shift left, and you know...
Been in organizations where you say,
"I need you to solve this vulnerability," and you know,
"I need you to change your sprint."
Most product developers are like,
"I need to push this capability out."
Capability makes them money.
So they're driven by capability pushes, right?
Sure.
So if you actually have a conversation and say,
"Look, we need to slow it down.
Maybe it's not this sprint.
Maybe it's the next sprint.
And we need to put in these security gates
to make sure we're pushing out secure code."
So under the NIST SSDF model out there.
I said, if you go to any customer and say,
"Customer X, could I get an extra one week
so I can produce a secure software?"
They'll always say yes.
True.
There's no customer that's not going to do that, right?
So I always go back to fundamentals
of actually being open, being communicative.
The word, you know,
we're always known as is "big brother's watching."
The cops.
We're not.
We're actually not.
And if you go down the different path, then it's like,
"Look, okay, it's not going to be this sprint,
it'll be the next sprint."
"Sounds good."
They might need sign off from their Chief Product Officer
to make sure, you know, they're okay with it.
But at least it's now you're building a community
and you're building a reason why we're doing this.
Versus like, oh, security is forcing us to do something.
That's fantastic.
As a CISO, you know,
you're charged with protecting the organization
and putting in all the different security programs
and mechanisms to make it as safe as possible
to do business,
but you're also charged
with enabling the company to innovate.
Yes.
Right?
How do you balance the two?
It's very delicate, right?
So being a startup, we are, you know,
velocity is everything.
Scalability is everything.
Customer demands are also...
You have a product, you have capability,
and Customer X wants this, Customer Y wants that, right?
So it goes back to the product roadmap, right?
So you really have to, as CISOs,
or any kind of security posture,
you have to get a seat in the table
where you're talking about the product roadmap.
When you're having the E-staff sit there
and talk about what the next quarter looks like,
what the next year looks like,
and being part of those conversations.
That's where I think you actually get that innovation.
And if I take it back one more step,
as a CISO, you might learn something
that you need to change on the security side
because you know some product innovation is coming in
and you need to make it easier for them, right?
So of course someone says, "Oh, MFA."
I'm like, "No. That's non-negotiable."
Right.
Everyone's got to have that.

That's going to happen, right?
Right.
But there are ways we can, as security practitioners,
make it easier for developers
so then they don't actually have to go
through hoops and ladders to get their work done too.
That's very, very cool.
Many CISOs are, I won't say challenged,
but they have limited security staff within the organization
and they're always trying to find ways
to increase the performance and the influence
that the security team has
across non-security parts of the organization.
So developers, service teams, maybe it's accounting,
maybe finance, HR, whatever the case may be.
How do you think about that?
And then how do you position the security culture
in your organization to really make sure
that security is everyone's job?
That is tough.
It's not easy because marketing wants something different.
Finance wants something different.
Sales folks who are traveling different countries,
different states, you know,
they want ease of business, right?
Especially in economic times like today.
We have less folks and we have less funding or less money,
but our responsibility hasn't changed.
Sure.
Right? So if our responsibility hasn't changed,
we have to basically find creative ways
to make this happen, right?
So one of the ways that I think that was really meaningful
at my previous company and this company
is when you have your team members meeting with a peer group
or organizations on security upfront,
again going back to education and communicating,
I don't go.
I actually don't go because I don't want it to be that,

"Oh, the CISO's here."
Oh, that's true.
Or "Oh, you know, leadership is here."
And you know, "We have to listen to the leadership."
Right?
I let our team members go communicate,
go build and foster those relationships, right?
Because then they're talking to their peer
or they're talking to their colleague.
So then when you actually start deploying it
across the company, it's actually more seamless, right?
Because you've actually done your homework,
done your due diligence.
You've built some allies.
You've built some allies,
but you build it without you being there.
Because as security leaders or the leaders in there
it's a whole different tone, a whole different game,
a whole different conversation.
"Oh, my boss is here, you know,
so we're got to talk about this.
I got to listen."
But I think it's you have to enable others
to do the same thing.
You have to, and it's really hard.
But I think you have to build that ecosystem,
have your individuals, team members,
be able to carry that baton
and be that security practitioner for everyone.
That's fantastic.
So with within your security team proper,
what kind of skills or traits or backgrounds
are you looking for
when you're hiring somebody for your security team?
The number one trait is curiosity.
I can't teach you to be curious.
Interesting.
I can teach you security and get you X, Y, Z training.
I can give you curriculums from a university,
but I can't teach you to be curious.
And security, as we all agree,
it's not the same thing every day.
It's changing from this day to next day to moving forward.
Right.
So when you have a curious mind,
you are able to adapt to different responses.
You get a vulnerability one day that says X.
Tomorrow the same vulnerability won't be X, it'll be Y.
And if you're curious enough and you're like,
"Okay, let me go drill down and click this button,"
and you are able to do that,
for me that's the number one reason, right?
So I use a very interesting test
that I use when I hire people.
I give them three words, hungry, humble, and smart.
And ask them to rank themselves
on whether you're hungry first, humble first,
or you're smart.
And it's always like for me to understand
what kind of dynamics to bring to the table.
Because if I had a whole team of all smart people...
We've all been there.
All smart people in one room, nothing would get done.
Because everyone thinks they're smarter
than the next person, right?
And if we had only humble people,
then no offense, but security will get run over
because we're just like, "Oh, okay, not today.
We'll do it tomorrow.
Not tomorrow. We'll do it later."
Right?
And if you have hungry people,
and if everyone's number one trait is, "I'm hungry first,"
you can't promote everyone every time.
So when we interview, we actually sit down
and my number one thing is,
"All right, everyone show me your hungry, humble, smart.
What did you think of what they were?"
So then they kind of...
You want to build the right equation of a team.
Sure.
You want to make sure the team is well balanced,
and depending on your ecosystem,
whether you're financial, retail, SaaS,
if you're like in crypto,
something you might need certain attributes to be higher.
Versus in certain industries
you might need certain attributes to be a little lower.
Right? So that's kind of how I look at building a team
or hiring a team within my security organization.
So it sounds like the diversity of the team

is the key element here.
It is.
Absolutely.
I mean, I have a team member in Canada.
I mean, I have a team member in the east coast.
I have a team member internationally.
Would I love for them to all be
in the Bay Area or be in the same office?
Yes.
But you know, it's not feasible.
Right?
I think Covid taught us all that.
And I think that diversity, that experience, that curiosity
only comes when you find different minded people.
That's awesome to hear.
Generative AI tools have been all over the news as of late.
What are your thoughts from a security perspective
as more and more people and I'm going to presume companies
are taking advantage of some of these tools?
Yeah, I think this is going to be innovation
that we're not ready for.
And it's going to be a lot of innovation
and it's going to be a lot of security
that we're going to need because of the speed and velocity
of how tools are being innovated and released.
We're trying to grow at scale, open source tools,
and the list kind of goes on.
What I think we are going to run into pretty quick
is going to be around the AI risk.
What is this risk exposure to your company,
to your customers?
Every contract that I know about
says third-party data cannot leave your environment
and go to a third-party source.
Now whether it's whichever AI model you want to use,
that data is now leaving your environment,
going to a third-party source,
and coming back and giving you some answer.
So I think there's going to be a lot of change
in how legal looks at it,
how risk is assumed by the customer, by the company.
And I think there's going to be a lot of innovation
in the space.
Is it the risk around the quote unquote black box
of these services?
Or what specifically about the risk is concerning?
I would say both. I mean, I think it's a black box,
because we don't know what we don't know, right?
Sure.
And one interesting thing that you and I probably agree on
is once you teach it something,
you can't just go back and say "delete," right?
Like you can't.
It's very expensive to go back and,
you know, take that out of the model, right?
So that's a trick that you're going to have to deal with
because you are going to get wrong information
and it's going to spoil the equation
and you're going to have to deal with that.
I think the risk will come in in terms of
where companies are going to be worried about what data
that they are giving this AI tool.
Mm-hmm.
And now is that AI tool public?
Are we all going to have AI internally in our house?
Like I think that all needs to be sorted out.
It's going to go at a speed that we're not prepared for.
And that risk that comes with it from a company perspective.
One thing I'll say is, like,
regulatory wise, I have no clue.
This is going to be...
Like, I don't even know how regulations
are going to kind of wrap their head around it,
because you have to find a way
to put some guardrails into it.
Otherwise it'll be a free-for-fall.
So basically leadership has to understand the risks
that they're going to undertake if they're going to agree
to use these tools as part of business.
Yeah. And then how do you control someone
who is in a different department,
who downloads one of these tools
and starts feeding it information?
And where does that information go?
Is there a tool today that alerts you or I that says,
"So-and-so fed this information this AI model.
That's a violation of your policy."
Well, perhaps there's a security opportunity here?
Yeah, I actually think there's going to be
a number of different security opportunities.
I do think it's going to be great for the environment too.
Along that same line of thought,
if we were to have this conversation five years from now,
what are we going to be talking about?
I think what we'll be talking about how
all our toil mundane work is actually all done for us.
I read an article recently where someone went
to one of these tools and said,
"I'm planning a trip to wine country.
It needs to be child-friendly.
It needs to have this budget and X, Y, and Z."
It went and did all the tasks, found a place, bocce ball,
sent an email, reserved it, put it on the calendar.
Mm-hmm.
Before there would be a person
that would call the different wineries
or Google different wineries or, you know,
use some sort of search engine to go figure something out.
But that's all going to be done, right?
So I think it'll be really interesting for us to see
in five years from now what we are focused on.
And I think it will be humans interpreting this data
so it's not just automated and just free-for-all, right?
I think we're going to have to have some human interaction
in every critical step
to make sure that it doesn't go down the wrong path.
And how are you going to have that conversation
with the board?
What do you think that's going to look like?
Yeah, we've already started
having conversations internally.
Like, you know, we have policies, we have principles.
It's not going to be easy.
This is not going to be easy.
It's going to take some time.
I don't have a good answer to it,
to be very transparent about it.
But I think this is where we should have more conversations.
We should have minds of CISOs who are,
"How are you tackling this?
How are you going to regulate this?"

Right?
Sure.
Because I think the more we talk about it,
then it'll be easier for us to protect each other
and keep the adversaries at bay.
Because adversaries are going to use this also.
It's an opportunity for everyone.
Yes, absolutely.
So in closing, any advice for your fellow CISOs?
Oh, I love advice from them.
(both laugh)
I would say the one thing that I've learned and, you know,
have also learned from my peer group
is get closer to your business.
You've got to be in that conversation with your CFO,
with your CRO, with your Chief Product Officer,
Chief Strategy Officer.
You've got to be closer to them
because that's what's going to help you realize
what's moving the bottom line,
what's protecting the company.
And then if you can be part of that conversation,
and having your capabilities,
helping them achieve their goals,
then the more customers you get,
the more, when you go back and ask for funding,
people understand why you're asking for funding.
So I think my advice would be
get closer to that group of folks,
understand their business and what drives them
will make an easier path for a CISO.
Sounds like great advice to me.
I keep trying it. I don't know.
Some days I'm successful and some days, you know, I'm not.
So we'll see.
Awesome.
Well, Aman, thank you so much for your time today.
Oh, I appreciate it.
Thank you so much.
